children.subject: Until now, I also thought it was hard to NP. I have a lot of unfinished assignments though, and I can't with good conscience ask the instructor to make an exception for me to pass as I simply haven't done the work required. I have reached out to the instructor, but I was wondering if anyone had advice on taking an incomplete and possibly not finishing vs. NPing in terms of grad school apps.

Which class is this? It's generally really hard to NP a class unless you've cheated or you're missing a whole bunch of assignments. Try reaching out to the instructors to see if there's any way you can pass the class now.
Okay, thank you Mouse! I'm applying next year. I thought I'd read something about being able to retain an I on your transcript? I could have misunderstood though...

If you're applying this year and have to choose one of the two, an Incomplete definitely looks better than an NP. It's my understanding that if you don't finish the missing class requirements, the Incomplete automatically becomes an NP. It's just the NP won't appear on your transcript for now as you need it.

history.content: This is such a hard question to answer. Maybe make an appointment to discuss this with an advisor? There are so many variables to consider, like what sort of grad program you're considering. If you're wanting to be a Ph.D. student, I would encourage you to complete the I, even if it's not in your area. If you're applying for a master's, you might be able to pull this off if the rest of your materials are strong enough.

I'm taking an upper div EECS class right now, and I've realized I don't have much interest in the field. I'm almost certainly going to NP the class at this rate, but I've also been considering requesting an Incomplete. However, given my lack of interest in the field and my limited time left at Berkeley, I don't exactly want to even take the class again in a future semester to resolve the Incomplete. I'll probably be applying to grad school in an unrelated field (still EECS though), so I was wondering: how bad does an NP look on a grad school application in this instance? Would it be worse or better to request an Incomplete and then retain the Incomplete grade permanently on record if I decide not to retake the class? Any advice is very much appreciated!
history.subject: How does NP or Incomplete look for grad schools?
